The FALL
of NATIONS
In recorded history there have been some twenty
civilizations on the world scene and many of them
rose to the pinnacle of world leadership, only to
fall and ultimately disappear. This film poses the
question: “How long is the lifetime of a nation?”
Then it examines the history of these nations: Old
Babylon, Ancient Egypt, Assyria, Egypt at the be¬
ginning of the Christian era; New Babylon, Phoeni¬
cia, Persia, Greece, and Rome. The actions and
conditions leading to the fall of each nation are
spotlighted. The lessons presented are these: No
nation which has risen to the pinnacle of world
leadership has ever stayed there for very long; the
three basic causes for the failure of nations are-
political, economic and moral decay. Dr. Ganus
suggests that these facts constitute a challenge to
the U. S. A.
Right: Egyptian culture was far advancecf, but ultimately slavery,
brought on by political and moral decay, heralded the downfall.
Above; in Rome, the downfall was hastened when food and enter¬
tainment was given to the populace by the government—private
business ended.
